results.title: In search of balance
results.creator_credit: National Recreation and Park Association and Anthony T Lorch
results.brief_description: A film to make communities aware of the value and need for recreation and park services. Illustrates passive and active recreation, solitary and group interaction and structured and unstructured activities. Also reveals the many concerns of environmentalists and conservationists and traces the origin of recreation as we know it today.

results.title: In search of Anna
results.creator_credit: Storm Productions, Australian Film Commission, Victorian Film Corporation and Esben Storm
results.brief_description: Tony has just been released from Pentridge after serving six years for robbery. He sets out to settle old scores and search for his girlfriend Anna. In the process he hitches a ride north with the enigmatic Sam and a relationship develops between them. The theme of coming to terms with the past is expressed formally through the non-chronological structure which produces a split narrative - the Melbourne scenes and the journey north - which inform each other as the story unfolds. Underlying the journey to awareness is the city/country antinomy - the country has the power to liberate what the city has entrapped. Features the music of AC/DC, Rose Tattoo, Stiletto, The Angels and Steve Wright. Cast includes Richard Moir, Judy Morris, Chris Haywood, Bill Hunter, Ian Nimmo, Maurie Fields.

results.title: In praise of love = Eloge de l'amour
results.creator_credit: Avventura Films, Studio Canal+, Les Films Alain Sarde and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description: In the first part of ‘In Praise of love’ a man is intent on auditioning actors for a film he is making on the relationship between a man and a woman who met in the Resistance to fascism in World War Two. Filmed in stark contrasts of black and white, the film within a film takes second place to philosophical mediations on the replacement of “history by technology” and the displacement of “politics by gospel”. In the film’s last third, the stock changes from black and white film to digital video and the colours have the vividness and expression of post-impressionist painting. An elderly couple are being courted by Hollywood executives to sell their story of meeting in the Resistance and surviving the Holocaust. Their antagonistic grand-daughter, reminding them that Schindler’s widow did not share in the wealth generated by Spielberg’s film of ‘Schindler’s List’, argues against the monolithic tendency of Hollywood to exchange in, profit from, and trivialise the lived experience of others. She also reminds us that her grandparents’ history mirrors that of French philosopher Simone Weil, whose social humanism is of no interest to the business people from Los Angeles. What does all this have to do with love? ‘In Praise of love’ reminds us that not only did Jean-Luc Godard re-invent the grammar of film but that he is also one of cinema’s great romanticists. The discordant sounds and jump-cuts of his earlier films have given way to a more mediative mise-en-scene, but his experimentation with sound and image are still provoking and exciting. This film is a philosophical essay on the changing faces of love, an argument against Hollywood’s monopoly of the image, a melancholy ode to a vanishing Paris, an examination on age, passion and politics, and a celebration of the possibilities in both film and video. At the twilight of his life, Godard has created an ode that still argues for the importance and value in something called history, in something called cinema. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: In praise of hands
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Colin Low and Donald Winkler
results.brief_description: A tribute to the craftsmen everywhere whose work adds colour and richness to life. Filmed in the Canadian Arctic, Finland, India, Nigeria, Japan, Mexico, and Poland, it shows the special skills of artisans working at their crafts - stone sculpture, pottery, ceramics, weaving, dyeing, puppet making, embroidery. Each indigenous skill is a reflection of the culture of the country. Film without words. (Award: Moscow)

results.title: In parliament assembled
results.brief_description: The traditions and procedures of Britain’s Parliament. An introduction by Daniel Farson is followed by interviews with General Sir Brian Horrocks (Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod), Sir Edward Bridges (Secretary to Sir Winston Churchill’s wartime Cabinet), W.S. Morrison (then Speaker of the House of Commons) and three Members of Parliament representing the principal parties. Each discusses his own part in the procedures of Parliament.

results.title: In our water
results.brief_description: South Brunswick, New Jersey; Spring, 1975. Frank Kaler and his family are convinced there is something wrong with their water; vegetables cooked in it change colour, skin lesions appear after bathing in it. The health department claims that it is drinkable, but it is later determined to be some of the most toxic drinking water in the country.
